discussion.content:
Correct.
With Cloud OnRamp for IaaS, vManage will automatically deploy SD-WAN edge virtual routers in a transit VPC, acting as virtual aggregation routers.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/solutions/collateral/enterprise-networks/sd-wan/white-paper-c11-742817.html

C

To extend the in-house Cisco SD-WAN branch network into AWS, the network architect can leverage Cisco Cloud onRamp for IaaS. Here’s how it works:

Cisco SD-WAN Cloud onRamp for IaaS: This solution automates and optimizes secure network connectivity from private network campus and branch locations to Amazon Web Services (AWS) virtual private clouds (VPCs). It streamlines the process and ensures a secure connection between your branches and AWS workloads.
Deployment Steps:
Verify prerequisites (ensure valid certificates for SD-WAN controllers).
Deploy a transit VPC with Cisco Cloud onRamp for IaaS.
Discover and map host VPCs to the transit VPC.
Monitor Cisco Cloud onRamp for IaaS.
Benefits:
Fully automated extension of the Cisco SD-WAN fabric to AWS Cloud.
Secure connectivity in minutes, replacing manual processes.
Seamless integration with AWS workloads

Selected Answer: D
Correct D
correct.

questions.question_text:
A large retail organization decided to move some of the branch applications to the AWS cloud. How does the network architect extend the in-house Cisco SD-
WAN branch to cloud network into AWS?

choices.C: Install the AWS Cloud Router in the main data center and provide the connectivity from each branch
choices.A: Create virtual instances of vSmart Cloud through the AWS online software store
choices.D: Create virtual WAN Edge devices Cloud through the AWS online software store
choices.B: Create GRE tunnels to AWS from each branch over the Internet

questions.question_text: An engineer is tasked to improve throughput for connection-oriented traffic by decreasing round-trip latency. Which configuration will achieve this goal?

discussion.content:
This is the only option would be for TCP optimization to occur to improve throughout across a link.
C. turn on Enable TCP Optimization
nat on transport + centralize data policy

Should be D & E.
NAT for DIA + Centralised data policy for QoS config

Selected Answer: DE
agree with network_nick
answer should be D and E

Selected Answer: DE
Must configure NAT on the transport interface for DIA to function (D)

A centralized data policy can be used to match based on DSCP markings. Question specifies the DIA policy is based on matching QoS parameters, which is equivalent to matching on DSCP markings, accomplished via a centralized data policy (E).
D & E should be correct answers.

Selected Answer: AD
A- QOS Policy for this specific WAN Edge Router
D- Nat for DIA

Selected Answer: DE
These are the correct ones

Selected Answer: DE
D and E

Selected Answer: CD
For QoS you would utilize "Localized" Data Policy so I believe option E is not an option for QoS config, but for DIA. You would also need NAT and qos-map on the egress transport interface so my choice is C and D.

comments.content: After reading this again, the Correct answer is D and E. Centralized Data Policy can be used to configure QoS.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: DE
ANSWER D & E ARE CORRECTS!
https://www.cisco.com/c/dam/en/us/td/docs/solutions/CVD/SDWAN/sdwan-dia-deploy-2020aug.pdf
PAGE 13

I guess A&D is correct answer:
- you are question to enable the policy on a specific router (not central)
- NAT must be enabled on transport interface for DIA
Correct Answer : D/E

I think A & E

From the reference:
Centralized data policies are used in configuring application firewalls, service chaining,traffic engineering, and quality of service (QoS). These policies include ApplicationAware Routing to apply SLAs for applications and traffic steering as well as activating AppQoE features such as packet duplication.
C, E is correct

questions.question_text: An engineer is configuring a WAN Edge router for DIA based on matching QoS parameters. Which two actions accomplish this task? (Choose two.)

choices.A: Apply a data policy on WAN interface
choices.D: Configure NAT on the transport interface

discussion.content: C - check the number of zeroes

The answer is [D} even though their are typo's everywhere,

Policy rate is measured in bps (bits per second)
Burst rate is measured in bytes.

In order to achieve 10MB for the rate, the bps would need to be 10,000,000, not 1,000,000
This must be a type, however it is the closest answer out of the options.

Answer [D]

Cisco white paper:-
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/sdwan/configuration/policies/vedge/policies-book/data-policies.html

D is correct

D is the correct answer.
